ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.

Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Not much, its senior research, not a class that's made for learning
I learned how to conduct an independent research project in a topic I am excited about with excellent mentors.
I learned how physics research is conducted in a real world setting.
Physics research, presentation, report weighting
research

This course introduces you to what it is like to interact with members in a lab and collaborate on interesting projects. Many of the "skills" such as data analysis, presenting results, and writing reports are not taught, but you are given ample time and resources if you need assistance along the way.
Self guided research, presenting over zoom

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: More help finding an advisor would have been nice, you're basically on your own and most professors just won't respond to you or take weeks to do so. It was almost impossible to get an advisor.

The strengths of this course include the freedom to choose any topic for research and the lax deliverables. Students are only required to submit a 1 page proposal, 5 page midterm report, and 5-10 page final report. The course could be improved by providing feedback on these deliverables, however.

Your experience is very dependent on the group youre doing research in and your specific project. However, it might be helpful to have a sort of office hours for the final presentation where students could receive feedback on their draft slides and learn techniques for effective scientific presentation. Especially in science, I think there a few basic things that people can do that really elevate the quality and clarity of any presentation, and it would help immensely to have some sort of formal session on how to present your research
It was a great course!

Strengths: concise and well organized assignments (professor commitment, mid-term report, final report, final presentation)

Weaknesses: Difficult to find a lab to work in at the beginning of the semester. Email professors early and often if this is your first time researching at Yale.
Great!

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If you have research you enjoy and want credit for take it, if you're a senior and have to take it, take it. If not, find something else the will be more meaningful and a better use of your time.
I would recommend this course to any student excited to conduct physics research. However, this is a moot point for physics majors who are required to take this course.
If you want to do research and get credit for it, yes.
Definitely, it gives you the skills if you want to go into physics professionally !
required
If you're at all interested in research, I would definitely recommend trying it out. This isn't really a 'course', more of just a framework to set you up doing research for a semester.
Yes! To be a ohysics maior
